segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Create permanent shared objects security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Create permanent shared objects security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Create permanent shared objects security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Create permanent shared objects security policy setting.

segment.source: This user right determines which accounts can be used by processes to create a directory object by using the object manager.
segment.target: This user right determines which accounts can be used by processes to create a directory object by using the object manager.

segment.source: Directory objects include Active Directory objects, files and folders, printers, registry keys, processes, and threads.
segment.target: Directory objects include Active Directory objects, files and folders, printers, registry keys, processes, and threads.

segment.source: Users who have this capability can create permanent shared objects, including devices, semaphores, and mutexes.
segment.target: Users who have this capability can create permanent shared objects, including devices, semaphores, and mutexes.

segment.source: This user right is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.
segment.target: This user right is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.

segment.source: Because components that are running in kernel-mode inherently have this user right assigned to them, it is not necessary to specifically assign it.
segment.target: Because components that are running in kernel-mode inherently have this user right assigned to them, it is not necessary to specifically assign it.

segment.source: Users who have the Create permanent shared objects user right could create new shared objects and expose sensitive data to the network.
segment.target: Users who have the Create permanent shared objects user right could create new shared objects and expose sensitive data to the network.

segment.source: Therefore, do not assign this right to any users.
segment.target: Therefore, do not assign this right to any users.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, LocalSystem is the only account that has this right.
segment.target: By default, LocalSystem is the only account that has this right.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Users who have the Create permanent shared objects user right could create new shared objects and expose sensitive data to the network.
segment.target: Users who have the Create permanent shared objects user right could create new shared objects and expose sensitive data to the network.

segment.source: Do not assign the Create permanent shared objects user right to any users.
segment.target: Do not assign the Create permanent shared objects user right to any users.

segment.source: Processes that require this user right should use the System account, which already includes this user right, instead of a separate user account.
segment.target: Processes that require this user right should use the System account, which already includes this user right, instead of a separate user account.

segment.source: Not Defined is the default configuration.
segment.target: Not Defined is the default configuration.
